Hail up to the size of golf balls was reported west of the I-55 corridor in Mason County before the event transitioned to primarily damaging wind gusts of 60-70mph as the storms pushed eastward to the Indiana border.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 0.6 miles west of Cisco at 1:10 AM CDT.  The tornado tracked eastward through the north side of Cisco.  Numerous trees were damaged, several of which fell onto buildings.  The tornado dissipated 0.8 miles northeast of Cisco at 1:12 AM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front interacting with a moderately unstable and sheared environment triggered several lines of strong to severe thunderstorms during the late evening of May 22nd into the pre-dawn hours of May 23rd.  Five tornadoes developed along the leading edge of the storms, including an EF-1 tornado that caused minor damage across portions of Sangamon, Menard, and Logan counties.  Hail up to the size of golf balls was reported west of the I-55 corridor in Mason County before the event transitioned to primarily damaging wind gusts of 60-70mph as the storms pushed eastward to the Indiana border.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 1 mile east of Fithian at 2:06 AM CDT.  The tornado tracked northeastward through the community of Muncie, damaging numerous trees and snapping power poles.  A house was damaged when a tree fell onto it, and a semi was blown off I-74.  The tornado dissipated 1 mile northeast of Muncie at 2:08 AM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front interacting with a moderately unstable and sheared environment triggered several lines of strong to severe thunderstorms during the late evening of May 22nd into the pre-dawn hours of May 23rd.  Five tornadoes developed along the leading edge of the storms, including an EF-1 tornado that caused minor damage across portions of Sangamon, Menard, and Logan counties.  Hail up to the size of golf balls was reported west of the I-55 corridor in Mason County before the event transitioned to primarily damaging wind gusts of 60-70mph as the storms pushed eastward to the Indiana border.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in an open field about 3.3 miles west-southwest of Xenia at 8:15 AM CDT.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front sagging into southeast Illinois triggered showers and thunderstorms south of the I-70 corridor during the morning of May 23rd.  One cell produced a brief tornado southwest of Xenia in Clay County, while other storms dropped heavy rainfall and caused localized flash flooding.  With 1-2 inches of rain falling in a short period of time, several county roads north of US-50 were flooded in Richland County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high-end EF1 tornado uprooted and snapped large trees and destroyed outbuildings at two farmsteads, and snapped some power poles.  The tornado was on the ground for about 5 minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northward into the area Friday, May 24, sparking widespread thunderstorms in the morning/early afternoon time frame and again in the early evening. Two tornadoes were occurred in McDonough County during the early afternoon. Towards evening, another tornadic storm developed, producing two tornadoes. The first occurred in Johnson County just southwest of Iowa City, and the second in Cedar County just north of West Branch.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The second of two tornadoes quickly developed and snapped power poles before hitting a farmstead, where it snapped trees and destroyed outbuildings.  The tornado was on the ground for about 4 minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northward into the area Friday, May 24, sparking widespread thunderstorms in the morning/early afternoon time frame and again in the early evening. Two tornadoes were occurred in McDonough County during the early afternoon. Towards evening, another tornadic storm developed, producing two tornadoes. The first occurred in Johnson County just southwest of Iowa City, and the second in Cedar County just north of West Branch.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down between Ipava and Lewistown, moving to the east. A few tree limbs were torn down before the tornado dissipated after tracking for a little more than one mile.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary interacting with an unstable airmass triggered widely scattered strong to severe thunderstorms across west-central Illinois during the afternoon and evening of May 24th.  One storm produced a brief tornado west of Lewistown in Fulton County, while other cells created damaging wind gusts of around 60 mph and hail as large as golf balls.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down along the leading edge of a line of thunderstorms about 3.5 miles west-northwest of Green Valley at 11:14 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northeastward, damaging the roof of a manufactured home and several trees before dissipating 2.6 miles northwest of Green Valley at 11:16 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated supercells developed ahead of an approaching cold front across west-central Illinois during the late evening of May 25th.  The storms eventually congealed into a line and tracked eastward along and north of the I-72 corridor to the Indiana border by the pre-dawn hours of May 26th.  Five tornado touchdowns occurred along the leading edge of the storms, including two in Tazewell County and three in Champaign County.  Aside from the tornadoes, the storms produced 60-70 mph wind gusts and hail as large as quarters.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down about 0.9 miles north-northeast of Green Valley at 11:19 PM CDT.  The tornado uprooted a tree, damaged an irrigation unit, and did significant damage to a large shed before dissipating 1.5 miles northeast of Green Valley at 11:20 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated supercells developed ahead of an approaching cold front across west-central Illinois during the late evening of May 25th.  The storms eventually congealed into a line and tracked eastward along and north of the I-72 corridor to the Indiana border by the pre-dawn hours of May 26th.  Five tornado touchdowns occurred along the leading edge of the storms, including two in Tazewell County and three in Champaign County.  Aside from the tornadoes, the storms produced 60-70 mph wind gusts and hail as large as quarters.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down within a line of severe thunderstorms near Mayfair Road and Broadmoor Drive in Champaign at 11:23 PM CDT May 25th.  The tornado damaged numerous trees as it moved to the east-southeast parallel to Broadmoor Drive before dissipating near Richards Lane and Park Haven Drive in Champaign at 11:25 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated supercells developed ahead of an approaching cold front across west-central Illinois during the late evening of May 25th.  The storms eventually congealed into a line and tracked eastward along and north of the I-72 corridor to the Indiana border by the pre-dawn hours of May 26th.  Five tornado touchdowns occurred along the leading edge of the storms, including two in Tazewell County and three in Champaign County.  Aside from the tornadoes, the storms produced 60-70 mph wind gusts and hail as large as quarters.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near Race Street and McHenry Street in Urbana at 11:27 PM CDT May 25th.  The tornado damaged numerous trees as it traveled to the east-southeast just south of McHenry Street before dissipating west of Philo Road in Urbana at 11:29 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated supercells developed ahead of an approaching cold front across west-central Illinois during the late evening of May 25th.  The storms eventually congealed into a line and tracked eastward along and north of the I-72 corridor to the Indiana border by the pre-dawn hours of May 26th.  Five tornado touchdowns occurred along the leading edge of the storms, including two in Tazewell County and three in Champaign County.  Aside from the tornadoes, the storms produced 60-70 mph wind gusts and hail as large as quarters.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down about 1.3 miles southwest of St. Joseph at 11:35 PM CDT May 25th.  The tornado crossed Salt Fork and damaged trees along County Road 2200 East before dissipating 1 mile south of St. Joseph at 11:37 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated supercells developed ahead of an approaching cold front across west-central Illinois during the late evening of May 25th.  The storms eventually congealed into a line and tracked eastward along and north of the I-72 corridor to the Indiana border by the pre-dawn hours of May 26th.  Five tornado touchdowns occurred along the leading edge of the storms, including two in Tazewell County and three in Champaign County.  Aside from the tornadoes, the storms produced 60-70 mph wind gusts and hail as large as quarters.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down near the intersection of Walker Road and Ashley Road.  A video of the tornado showed it kicked up dust in an open field.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 27th producing large hail, wind damage and four tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado moved through portions of southwest Romeoville, tracking just north of Lewis University Airport.  Damage was relatively minor, consisting mostly of light roof damage, leaning utility poles, and tree limbs blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 27th producing large hail, wind damage and four tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in an open field 1.1 miles south of Dahinda at 3:15 PM CDT.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a warm front draped across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 27th.  The storms produced numerous funnel clouds and two brief tornado touchdowns.  Further south, an isolated cell dropped golf ball sized hail in Clark County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on trained spotter reports, a brief tornado occurred just east of Interstate 39, southwest of Paw Paw.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 27th producing large hail, wind damage and four tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado moved through part of Sauk Village producing minor roof damage.  A light pole was blown down onto a car.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 27th producing large hail, wind damage and four tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in an open field 3.4 miles northwest of Benson at 4:38 PM CDT.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a warm front draped across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 27th.  The storms produced numerous funnel clouds and two brief tornado touchdowns.  Further south, an isolated cell dropped golf ball sized hail in Clark County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in an open field 5.1 miles south-southwest of Henning at 4:06 PM CDT.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widely scattered severe thunderstorms developed along a stationary frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 28th.  One cell produced a brief tornado touchdown in Vermilion County, while another storm dropped tennis ball-sized hail in DeLand in Piatt County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado touched down in an open field about 3.8 miles north-northwest of Stonington at 4:28 PM CDT.  The tornado dissipated 2 minutes later with no damage being reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of thunderstorms developed along a nearly stationary frontal boundary draped across central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of May 29th.  Four landspout type tornadoes touched down beneath developing cells across portions of Christian and Macon counties.  Other storms produced isolated wind damage and hail as large as quarters.  In addition, numerous cells training over the same locations dropped as much as 2 to 3 inches of rainfall in a short period of time along the I-70 corridor.  As a result, localized flash flooding occurred across portions of Effingham and Clark counties, with the most significant flooding taking place in West Union in Clark County where several feet of water was flowing across town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado touched down in an open field about 5.4 miles north-northwest of Edinburg at 4:30 PM CDT.  The tornado dissipated 2 minutes later with no damage being reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of thunderstorms developed along a nearly stationary frontal boundary draped across central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of May 29th.  Four landspout type tornadoes touched down beneath developing cells across portions of Christian and Macon counties.  Other storms produced isolated wind damage and hail as large as quarters.  In addition, numerous cells training over the same locations dropped as much as 2 to 3 inches of rainfall in a short period of time along the I-70 corridor.  As a result, localized flash flooding occurred across portions of Effingham and Clark counties, with the most significant flooding taking place in West Union in Clark County where several feet of water was flowing across town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado touched down in an open field about 4.1 miles northeast of Stonington at 4:35 PM CDT.  The tornado dissipated 3 minutes later with no damage being reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of thunderstorms developed along a nearly stationary frontal boundary draped across central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of May 29th.  Four landspout type tornadoes touched down beneath developing cells across portions of Christian and Macon counties.  Other storms produced isolated wind damage and hail as large as quarters.  In addition, numerous cells training over the same locations dropped as much as 2 to 3 inches of rainfall in a short period of time along the I-70 corridor.  As a result, localized flash flooding occurred across portions of Effingham and Clark counties, with the most significant flooding taking place in West Union in Clark County where several feet of water was flowing across town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado touched down in an open field about 2.1 miles east of Blue Mound at 4:50 PM CDT.  The tornado dissipated 6 minutes later with no damage being reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of thunderstorms developed along a nearly stationary frontal boundary draped across central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of May 29th.  Four landspout type tornadoes touched down beneath developing cells across portions of Christian and Macon counties.  Other storms produced isolated wind damage and hail as large as quarters.  In addition, numerous cells training over the same locations dropped as much as 2 to 3 inches of rainfall in a short period of time along the I-70 corridor.  As a result, localized flash flooding occurred across portions of Effingham and Clark counties, with the most significant flooding taking place in West Union in Clark County where several feet of water was flowing across town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down on a farm causing minor damage to an outbuilding, about 3 miles west northwest of Millstadt, then tracked to the southeast.  It caused minor damage to a house on Franken Strasse Drive.  The garage door was blown in, a window on an exterior door was broken and there was minor siding damage. The tornado then lifted and dissipated. Overall the tornado was rated EF0 with a path length of 0.53 miles and a max path width of 10 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and storms developed across the region. One storm over St. Clair County produced a brief tornado just west northwest of Millstadt, Illinois.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado was observed and photographed by several individuals including a storm chaser and severe storm spotter. This damage survey is based on video and times provided by the individuals along with estimates from radar. The weak tornado moved west to east across the northern portions of Benld producing damage to trees and power lines and minor damage to several homes. Damage information was provided by emergency management officials. The tornado was rated EF0 with a path length of 1.82 miles and a max path width of 30 yards.  No deaths or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: MCV moved through region during the afternoon hours on June 15th with some isolated supercells. Then main cold front moved through during the late evening and overnight hours with a line of convection. There was one tornado and several reports of damaging winds and large hail with this event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado damaged trees at and just east of a farmstead. Some trunks were snapped off near the base. Maximum wind speeds were estimated around 100 mph. The tornado was on the ground for about 1 minute. The time was estimated by radar, and the damage was observed and documented by emergency management.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms tracked across portions of eastern Iowa, northeast Missouri, and northwest Illinois Saturday evening, June 15,  bringing damaging winds, heavy downpours, frequent lightning, large hail, and a tornado.  Many areas saw winds between 30-50 mph during the evening hours, with higher winds of 60-70 mph reported in Iowa and Benton counties in Iowa.   ||The storms produced three tornadoes in Des Moines County (west of  Mediapolis, IA and south of Oakville, IA) between 7:50 pm and 8:30 pm.||Two tornadoes south of Oakville were rated EF2 and downed numerous trees, severely damaged a house displacing it off its foundation, destroyed outbuildings, and downed power poles.||The tornado west of Mediapolis remained in an open field and was rated EF0.||Another tornado occurred just northeast of Keithsburg in Mercer County Illinois. This tornado was rated EF1 and trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 2.1 miles southwest of South Pekin at 10:19 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked east-southeast...destroying a shed, blowing over several 18 to 24-inch diameter trees, and knocking over power poles north of Christmas Tree Road near Highway 29 before dissipating about 2.4 miles southeast of South Pekin at 10:22 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed across eastern Iowa during the early evening of June 15th, then tracked southeastward along an advancing warm front into central Illinois during the late evening of the 15th into the early morning hours of the 16th.  Two tornadoes touched down along the leading edge of the storms...one just southwest of South Pekin in Tazewell County and another near Bellflower in McLean County.  Minor damage was reported with both tornadoes.  Elsewhere around the area, 50-60 mph wind gusts caused scattered damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 1.3 miles north of Bellflower at 11:36 PM CDT.  The tornado destroyed a machine shed along 3850 E Road before dissipating about 2.8 miles northeast of Bellflower at 11:39 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed across eastern Iowa during the early evening of June 15th, then tracked southeastward along an advancing warm front into central Illinois during the late evening of the 15th into the early morning hours of the 16th.  Two tornadoes touched down along the leading edge of the storms...one just southwest of South Pekin in Tazewell County and another near Bellflower in McLean County.  Minor damage was reported with both tornadoes.  Elsewhere around the area, 50-60 mph wind gusts caused scattered damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down about 2 miles west of Moweaqua. It damaged crops before dissipating in less than one minute.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure tracking along a nearly stationary frontal boundary triggered several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms across central Illinois during the afternoon and early evening of June 19th.  Two weak tornadoes briefly touched down producing minor damage; one in northeast Christian County and one in central Moultrie County.  Other thunderstorm cells produced strong wind gusts and minor damage in Robinson in Crawford County.  In addition, excessive rainfall rates caused localized flash flooding along a creek on the northeast side of Bethany in Moultrie County.  Dive teams rescued 4 people and a dog from a car that had been swept off a road by the rapidly rising water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several storm chasers took video of a short-lived and weak tornado that lasted an estimated 10-15 seconds. The tornado appeared to be over an open field as no damage was found or observed in the video. Tornado location was estimated based on reports and radar. The tornado was rated EF0 with a path length of 0.08 miles and a max path width of 25 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms developed over portions of southern Illinois on June 19th. One storm produced a weak tornado near Cartter, IL that was observed by storm chasers and they caught it on video as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in an open field about 2.3 miles east of Bethany at 7:22PM CDT.  Crops sustained minor damage before the tornado dissipated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure tracking along a nearly stationary frontal boundary triggered several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms across central Illinois during the afternoon and early evening of June 19th.  Two weak tornadoes briefly touched down producing minor damage; one in northeast Christian County and one in central Moultrie County.  Other thunderstorm cells produced strong wind gusts and minor damage in Robinson in Crawford County.  In addition, excessive rainfall rates caused localized flash flooding along a creek on the northeast side of Bethany in Moultrie County.  Dive teams rescued 4 people and a dog from a car that had been swept off a road by the rapidly rising water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado occurred in the Shawnee National Forest north-northwest of Golconda. The tornado began along Clark Road and tracked northeast, ending northeast of the Highway 146/Buschwack Road junction. Dozens of trees were uprooted or snapped. A home lost some shingles, and a small shed lost part of its roof. Peak winds were estimated near 95 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms entered southeast Missouri about mid-afternoon and tracked east across western Kentucky and far southern Illinois late in the afternoon and early in the evening. In far southern Illinois, an EF-1 tornado was associated with this line. The storms occurred under a rather strong southwest wind flow ahead of a weak cold front over far western Missouri. A 500 mb shortwave trough over the western high Plains provided some additional support for the storms. The air mass was strongly unstable, with surface capes over 3000 j/kg.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several photos showed a landspout tornado east southeast of Gilman.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful line of thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 30th producing wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was reported near 1700 East and 2400 North, east of Ashkum.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of July 21st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down about 2.7 miles east-southeast of Edinburg at 9:08 PM CDT.  The tornado moved southeastward along County Road 1100 East north of County Road 2000 North, flattening an extensive area of corn, stripping half the roof off a machine shed, and snapping several large trees.  Further southeast along County Highway 22 north of County Road 1900 North, numerous trees were damaged and two semi trailers were tipped over.  Along County Road 1400 East north of 1800 North, a large tree was snapped and the roof of a house was damaged.  The tornado dissipated just before reaching State Highway 48 about 4.1 miles northeast of Taylorville at 9:21 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching warm front triggered numerous clusters of severe thunderstorms across portions of central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of August 12th.  The storms were mainly focused along and just south of the I-72 corridor.  Given the large amount of low-level wind shear in the environment near the boundary, many of the cells began rotating.  Two tornadoes touched down, impacting northern Christian County into far western Shelby County.  Elsewhere around the area, scattered wind damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down about 1.2 miles north of Assumption at 9:40 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked east-southward, breaking several large tree limbs at a home, which punched a hole in the roof of the home.  Along County Road 2650 East, a trailer was overturned and pushed into an outbuilding.  The tornado then crossed into Shelby County 1.6 miles northeast of Assumption at 9:43 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching warm front triggered numerous clusters of severe thunderstorms across portions of central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of August 12th.  The storms were mainly focused along and just south of the I-72 corridor.  Given the large amount of low-level wind shear in the environment near the boundary, many of the cells began rotating.  Two tornadoes touched down, impacting northern Christian County into far western Shelby County.  Elsewhere around the area, scattered wind damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado crossed from Christian County into far western Shelby County about 6.4 miles south of Moweaqua at 9:43 PM CDT.  Significant crop damage occurred near the county line before the tornado dissipated just before reaching County Road 700 East at 9:44 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching warm front triggered numerous clusters of severe thunderstorms across portions of central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of August 12th.  The storms were mainly focused along and just south of the I-72 corridor.  Given the large amount of low-level wind shear in the environment near the boundary, many of the cells began rotating.  Two tornadoes touched down, impacting northern Christian County into far western Shelby County.  Elsewhere around the area, scattered wind damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 3.5 miles southwest of Decatur just southeast of the Rock Springs Conservation Area at 7:59 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked eastward damaging a few tree branches, then quickly dissipated one minute later at 8:00 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak area of low pressure tracking along a nearly stationary frontal boundary triggered scattered thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of August 21st.  One cell produced a brief EF-0 tornado southwest of Decatur in Macon County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado touched down in an open field 7.9 miles south of Neoga at 2:31 PM CDT.  The tornado knocked over corn in the field before dissipating at 2:33 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado briefly touched down beneath a developing shower in western Cumberland County during the afternoon of September 1st.  Only minor crop damage was observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched downed just west of Twyford Road and moved east southeast through parts of Waukegan.  Damage from the tornado was minor to commercial buildings and residences, including windows blown out, minor roof damage, fence destruction and damage to a gas station canopy.  A vehicle was flipped over just east of the intersection of York House Road and Lewis Avenue where one minor injury occurred.  Numerous trees were blown down or suffered heavy branch damage.  The tornado was at its widest and strongest in the latter half of its path.  Estimated peak winds for this tornado were 90 mph.  A one mile stretch between the last damage point and the Lake Michigan shore was unable to be surveyed due a nature area in the Illinois Beach Nature Preserve.  A waterspout was reported just off shore and so by interpolation, the path for this tornado was continued to the Lake Michigan shore.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm moved across far northeast Illinois during the evening of September 3rd producing a tornado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in a wooded area of northeastern Fulton County 4.9 miles east-northeast of Canton at 8:22 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked southeastward, doing damage to numerous trees as it crossed County Highway 27 near North Orion School Road.  It did minor roof damage to several homes and a church, and downed additional trees and power poles before dissipating in an open field 3.8 miles north of Banner at 8:27 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of thunderstorms impacted north-central Illinois on September 27th.  Most of the convection remained focused north of a Quincy to Bloomington line...where several inches of rain occurred.  As much as 5 to 9 inches of rain fell from eastern Peoria County into northern Woodford and southern Marshall counties.  As a result of the excessive rainfall, major flash flooding was reported in the Peoria metro area, where several water rescues were performed.  Meanwhile a line of severe thunderstorms spawned an EF-0 tornado in northeastern Fulton County.  Minor tree and roof damage occurred along the path of the tornado.  Elsewhere around the area, other cells produced scattered wind damage and hail as large as golf balls.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in an open field along US-136 1.8 miles west-northwest of Emden at 4:18 PM CDT.  The tornado initially tracked nearly parallel to US-136 damaging tree limbs and crops, then turned to the east-southeast and passed about one quarter mile north of the village of Emden before dissipating in a field 1.1 miles east-northeast of Emden at 4:26 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front brought a summer-like airmass northward into central Illinois on September 29th as afternoon high temperatures topped out in the middle to upper 80s along and south of the I-72 corridor.  Widely scattered supercell thunderstorms developed along the front during the afternoon and early evening...with one long-lived cell producing hail as large as tennis balls in northern Fulton County and an EF-0 tornado in far northern Logan County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado snapped large tree branches in the town of Ware. Metal roofing was removed from a farm outbuilding. A large open storage building was overturned and destroyed. Shingles were removed from the roof of a hunting club. Another home had its roof lifted slightly by the tornado, causing water damage. The roof of a metal storage building was lofted and overturned. Hundreds of decoy ducks were tossed and broken near the hunting club. Numerous trees were snapped or uprooted along the path of the tornado. Peak winds were estimated near 100 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong storm system impacted the region January 10-11. Heavy rainfall, flooding, isolated damaging winds, a brief tornado, and gusty non-thunderstorm winds impacted southern Illinois during this time. The bulk of the event occurred overnight and into the morning hours on the 11th. Rainfall totals ranged from 2 to 5 inches, which resulted in widespread areal flooding and isolated flash flooding across the region. Smaller rivers such as the Little Wabash and the Skillet Fork went into moderate to major flooding. Strong to severe convection over the Ozark Mountains moved east into an environment of very strong wind shear over southeast Missouri, with 850 mb winds near 60 knots. Tremendous wind shear (winds of 50 knots down to 1500 feet above ground level) and strong forcing associated with a potent 500 mb shortwave compensated for weak instability. The convection weakened after it crossed the Mississippi River during the early morning hours. Some of the strong winds aloft reached the surface as gradient gusts from 40 to 49 mph, mainly along and south of a Carbondale to Harrisburg line. A weak surface low formed along a cold front over southwest Arkansas, then deepened as it tracked northeast across the Missouri Bootheel and into the lower Ohio Valley on the morning of the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado started near the community of Sunfield on U.S. Highway 51. At least a dozen homes were damaged, including four with major structural damage. This included numerous broken windows and roof damage. One home had part of its roof decking removed, and another had its attached garage blown apart from the house. At least five camper trailers were blown over, with one lofted over 200 yards across a field. Several outbuildings and garages were partly or completely levelled. Dozens of trees were snapped or uprooted. Some power lines were down. A trained spotter witnessed the tornado. The tornado path crossed Du Quoin Lake and ended on Highway 154. Peak winds were estimated near 100 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Short lines of thunderstorms with embedded circulations moved across southern Illinois during the afternoon of the 19th. Widespread heavy rain caused isolated flash flooding. The storms occurred just south of a warm front under a very strong southwest low level flow, around 60 knots at 850 mb. An upper level disturbance over the Ozark Mountains contributed to the storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the damage path occurred in Hamilton County, however the tornado started in extreme eastern Jefferson County.  In the short time the tornado was in Jefferson County, large branches were broken. Peak winds were in the EF-0 category in Jefferson County, but the tornado strengthened to EF-1 in Hamilton County. The tornado entered Hamilton County just west of the community of Dahlgren.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Short lines of thunderstorms with embedded circulations moved across southern Illinois during the afternoon of the 19th. Widespread heavy rain caused isolated flash flooding. The storms occurred just south of a warm front under a very strong southwest low level flow, around 60 knots at 850 mb. An upper level disturbance over the Ozark Mountains contributed to the storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado started in extreme eastern Jefferson County. The tornado moved across the northwest side of Dahlgren in Hamilton County. Several homes sustained roofing or soffit damage. One home had about a quarter of its roof removed and tossed about 50 yards. A few barns were damaged. Two travel trailers were overturned. Dozens of mature trees were snapped or uprooted. Peak winds were estimated near 110 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Short lines of thunderstorms with embedded circulations moved across southern Illinois during the afternoon of the 19th. Widespread heavy rain caused isolated flash flooding. The storms occurred just south of a warm front under a very strong southwest low level flow, around 60 knots at 850 mb. An upper level disturbance over the Ozark Mountains contributed to the storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in an open field 1 mile southwest of Oneida at 5:39 PM CDT.  No damage was observed before the tornado quickly dissipated one minute later.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The airmass across central Illinois became highly unstable and sheared during the afternoon of March 28th as a warm front lifted toward southern Wisconsin.  Due to a strong mid-level cap, thunderstorms failed to initiate until a dryline approached from the west by late afternoon into the evening.  The storms formed into a broken line as they pushed through the Illinois River Valley, spawning three tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports and photos confirm that a brief tornado occurred southwest of Cambridge Illinois on Saturday evening. There was no observable damage from which the NWS could assign an EF-scale rating for the tornado.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked from southwest Iowa to north central Iowa Saturday afternoon and evening. Storms developed and moved across a warm front in the area that resulted in two tornadoes touching down in northwest Illinois.Two additional tornadoes were reported in eastern Iowa.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 1.1 miles south-southeast of Ipava at 8:01 PM CDT.  The tornado damaged a barn, the roofs of two houses, a front porch, a gazebo, and numerous trees and outbuildings as it tracked northeastward across US-136 before dissipating 1.8 miles east of Ipava at 8:04 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The airmass across central Illinois became highly unstable and sheared during the afternoon of March 28th as a warm front lifted toward southern Wisconsin.  Due to a strong mid-level cap, thunderstorms failed to initiate until a dryline approached from the west by late afternoon into the evening.  The storms formed into a broken line as they pushed through the Illinois River Valley, spawning three tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-1 tornado with estimated wind speeds of 90 MPH. The tornado caused damage to a farm outbuilding and uprooted trees at a farmstead. The tornado flipped a farm irrigator before lifting.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked from southwest Iowa to north central Iowa Saturday afternoon and evening. Storms developed and moved across a warm front in the area that resulted in two tornadoes touching down in northwest Illinois.Two additional tornadoes were reported in eastern Iowa.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 0.3 miles east of the Peoria Airport at 8:58 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northeastward, doing minor damage to house roofs, fences and siding in a subdivision. Business roofs were then damaged at Madison Park Shopping Center and numerous trees at Madison Park Golf Course.  Several roofs were damaged in a nearby subdivision before the tornado dissipated near the eastern portion of St. Mary's Cemetery at 9:03 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The airmass across central Illinois became highly unstable and sheared during the afternoon of March 28th as a warm front lifted toward southern Wisconsin.  Due to a strong mid-level cap, thunderstorms failed to initiate until a dryline approached from the west by late afternoon into the evening.  The storms formed into a broken line as they pushed through the Illinois River Valley, spawning three tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down east of Oregon and tracked 7 miles across mainly rural portions of central Ogle County, dissipating just prior to reaching Stillman Valley.  The majority of the damage along the path was to trees and power lines, though there was some structural damage, primarily to outbuildings and barns.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the evening of March 28th.  These storms produced heavy rain and localized flooding as well as one tornado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 1.8 miles west-northwest of Dawson at 6:56 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked east-southeast across the south side of Dawson...damaging shingles, siding, and guttering on 12 homes before dissipating 0.3 miles east-southeast of Dawson at 7:01 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a line of strong thunderstorms across west-central Illinois during the late afternoon and early evening of April 28th.  A few of the cells produced hail as large as quarters and localized flash flooding.  Due to outflow and cell mergers, a brief tornado developed northwest of Dawson in eastern Sangamon County.  Minor house damage occurred in Dawson as the tornado quickly tracked through the south side of town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF1 tornado moved through rural Henry County, Illinois last Thursday night, May 14th. The tornado began around 10:16 pm CDT, and caused significant damage at a farmstead, with estimated maximum winds of 110 mph. The tornado nearly completely destroyed a 70 foot concrete silo, snapped the trunk of a large tree, completely destroyed two horse sheds, and damaged an equipment shed. The tornado then moved rapidly northeast along an intermittent four and a quarter mile path, and caused tree and outbuilding damage at two other farmsteads. The tornado lifted around 10:20 pm CDT. Times and begin/end locations were estimated by radar. Field assistance by the Henry County Emergency Manager and OEM volunteers to complete the remote survey is greatly appreciated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms tracked across central Iowa into eastern Iowa, northeast Missouri, and northwest Illinois late Friday afternoon and into the overnight hours. These storms brought heavy rain, frequent lightning, damaging winds, and large hail to the region.  The hardest hit areas were Keokuk county in Iowa, towards Henry county in Iowa, where 50-70 mph winds occurred.  A weak EF-1 tornado occurred near Atkinson, IL in Henry county in Illinois after 1015 pm and caused damage to trees and outbuildings at two farmsteads. ||Widespread rainfall amounts over 1 inch generally fell south of a line from Sigourney and Maquoketa, IA to Freeport, IL.  This rainfall combined with the previous days rain brought rain totals of 2-4 inches to the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado touched down in northwest Kendall County.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across many areas of northeast Illinois on May 17th producing widespread flooding which continued into May 18th.  Two brief tornadoes also occurred during the afternoon of May 17th.  Scattered showers produced a few funnel clouds on May 18th.  Some of the highest 48 hour rainfall totals ending Monday morning May 18th included 8.61 inches in River Forest; 5.18 inches near Oak Forest; 4.75 inches near Burr Ridge; 4.70 inches three miles southwest of Midway Airport; 4.59 inches in Palos Heights; 4.14 inches in Burr Ridge; 3.99 inches in Joliet; 3.88 inches in Harwood Heights; 3.80 inches at the National Weather Service office in Romeoville; 3.73 inches in Algonquin; 3.60 inches near Manhattan; 3.59 inches in Minooka; 3.59 inches at Chicago O'Hare Airport (ORD) and 3.32 inches in Cary.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in an open field 1.2 miles north-northeast of Macon at 4:06 PM CDT.  It tracked northeastward and dissipated about 1.1 miles east-northeast of Elwin at 4:14 PM CDT.  Minor damage to trees was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An advancing cold front triggered a line of thunderstorms during the afternoon of May 17th.  One of the cells embedded within the line spawned a brief tornado near Elwin in Macon County: however, no damage occurred.  Other storm cells produced wind gusts of around 60 mph that caused minor damage east of Robinson in Crawford County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado touched down in eastern Grundy County.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across many areas of northeast Illinois on May 17th producing widespread flooding which continued into May 18th.  Two brief tornadoes also occurred during the afternoon of May 17th.  Scattered showers produced a few funnel clouds on May 18th.  Some of the highest 48 hour rainfall totals ending Monday morning May 18th included 8.61 inches in River Forest; 5.18 inches near Oak Forest; 4.75 inches near Burr Ridge; 4.70 inches three miles southwest of Midway Airport; 4.59 inches in Palos Heights; 4.14 inches in Burr Ridge; 3.99 inches in Joliet; 3.88 inches in Harwood Heights; 3.80 inches at the National Weather Service office in Romeoville; 3.73 inches in Algonquin; 3.60 inches near Manhattan; 3.59 inches in Minooka; 3.59 inches at Chicago O'Hare Airport (ORD) and 3.32 inches in Cary.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado touched down beneath a developing shower 3.8 miles northeast of La Place at 6:07 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked very slowly northeastward through an open field for about 1 mile before dissipating at 6:15 PM CDT.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure triggered scattered showers across portions of central Illinois during the afternoon and evening of May 19th.  A weak landspout tornado touched down beneath one of the developing showers in southern Piatt County near Hammond.  No damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 1.1 miles southwest of Panola at 1:54 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northeastward through the small community of Panola damaging the roof of an outbuilding, cracking a window in a house, and knocking down several tree branches before dissipating 2.3 miles northeast of Panola at 1:59 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed near a warm front draped along the I-74 corridor during the early afternoon of May 23rd.  One of the cells spawned a brief EF-0 tornado in eastern Woodford County near Panola.  Other storms produced minor wind damage and hail as large as quarters across portions of Woodford and Tazewell counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A  tornado developed east/northeast of Morrison, IL in Whiteside County, shortly before 2:30 pm. The tornado followed an intermittent path northeast before hitting a farmstead near the Whiteside/Carroll County border. This tornado continued into Carroll County. The tornado snapped a 14 inch diameter tree, caused shingle damage, and downed power lines. The tornado was rated EF1 with maximum winds estimated around 100 mph. The tornado was on the ground for about 24 minutes along an intermittent 12 mile path.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms tracked across much of eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois in the early afternoon hours of May 23rd, 2020. Storms quickly intensified in an extremely favorable environment, which was the result of a warm front lifting north across the Midwest. Seven tornadoes were confirmed from this event in Iowa and Illinois.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A  tornado developed east/northeast of Morrison, IL in Whiteside County, shortly before 2:30 pm. The tornado followed an intermittent path northeast before hitting a farmstead near the Whiteside/Carroll County border. The tornado snapped a 14 inch diameter tree, caused shingle damage, and downed power lines. The tornado was rated EF1 with maximum winds estimated around 100 mph. The tornado was on the ground for about 24 minutes along an intermittent 12 mile path.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms tracked across much of eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois in the early afternoon hours of May 23rd, 2020. Storms quickly intensified in an extremely favorable environment, which was the result of a warm front lifting north across the Midwest. Seven tornadoes were confirmed from this event in Iowa and Illinois.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near Interstate 80, about a mile west of the Minooka exit.  The tornado blew over a car on Interstate 80, which resulted in one injury.  The tornado then moved into southeast Kendall County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 23rd producing wind damage, localized flooding and three tornadoes.  Several funnel clouds were also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in northeast Grundy County and moved into southeast Kendall County.  Two wooden utility poles were blown down along with a half dozen large trees and numerous large tree limbs.  The tornado continued into western Will County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 23rd producing wind damage, localized flooding and three tornadoes.  Several funnel clouds were also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in northeast Grundy County, moved into southeast Kendall County and then into far western Will County.  Numerous large tree limbs were blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 23rd producing wind damage, localized flooding and three tornadoes.  Several funnel clouds were also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter observed a brief tornado in an open field near Warren. The tornado is designated as an EF-U (unknown), as no damage was observed to assign an EF-scale rating.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms tracked across much of eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois in the early afternoon hours of May 23rd, 2020. Storms quickly intensified in an extremely favorable environment, which was the result of a warm front lifting north across the Midwest. Seven tornadoes were confirmed from this event in Iowa and Illinois.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the intersection of S Rocky Hollow and E Canfield Roads.  Peak winds were estimated between 90 mph and 100 mph based on damage to outbuildings and two farmsteads that were significantly damaged.  There were also several trees and utility poles blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 23rd producing wind damage, localized flooding and three tornadoes.  Several funnel clouds were also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the intersection of Roosevelt and Melms Road where a barn was damaged and debris from the barn was blown downstream into a field.  The tornado continued across fields until it crossed into Kane County where power lines were blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 23rd producing wind damage, localized flooding and three tornadoes.  Several funnel clouds were also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in De Kalb County and moved across fields in Kane County and dissipated before reaching Interstate 90.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of May 23rd producing wind damage, localized flooding and three tornadoes.  Several funnel clouds were also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A short-lived tornado was observed by several individuals from a distance. There were no reports of damage observed. The time and location was estimated from the reports and radar.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cutoff upper low remained over region with weak impulses rotating around it, helping to generate showers and a few severe thunderstorms through the early evening hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado touched down in an open field 5 miles north-northeast of Dunlap at 4:10 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northeastward and dissipated 1.1 miles east-northeast of Edelstein at 4:15 PM CDT.  No damage was observed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossing the Mississippi River triggered scattered thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of May 28th.  The storms produced 3 landspout tornadoes...one in Peoria County and two in Moultrie County.  In addition, other thunderstorm cells dropped 3 to 4 inches of rain in about an hour, causing significant flash flooding across western Marshall County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on multiple images and videos provided by several parties, a landspout tornado formed at approximately 2250 UTC and tracked along the I-55 corridor. The starting and ending points are estimated and based on information received.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front moved through the region, widespread showers and storms developed. Some of the storms produced damaging winds, large hail, flash flooding and even one isolated tornado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado briefly touched down in an open field 2.7 miles north-northeast of Bethany at 7:25 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked eastward and quickly dissipated one minute later.  No damage was observed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossing the Mississippi River triggered scattered thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of May 28th.  The storms produced 3 landspout tornadoes...one in Peoria County and two in Moultrie County.  In addition, other thunderstorm cells dropped 3 to 4 inches of rain in about an hour, causing significant flash flooding across western Marshall County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado briefly touched down near the Okaw River Bridge on Route 32 about 2 miles northwest of Lovington at 7:34 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked eastward and quickly dissipated one minute later.  No damage was observed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossing the Mississippi River triggered scattered thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of May 28th.  The storms produced 3 landspout tornadoes...one in Peoria County and two in Moultrie County.  In addition, other thunderstorm cells dropped 3 to 4 inches of rain in about an hour, causing significant flash flooding across western Marshall County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Photos from trained spotters showed a brief tornado that touched down southeast of Piper City and continued northeast into Iroquois County.  No damage was reported and the path was estimated based on reports from trained spotters.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across parts of northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 9th.  Additional thunderstorms moved across far eastern Illinois during the evening producing a tornado and a few funnel clouds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Photos from trained spotters showed a brief tornado that touched down southeast of Piper City in Ford County and continued northeast into Iroquois County, ending west northwest of Onarga.  No damage was reported and the path was estimated based on reports from trained spotters.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across parts of northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 9th.  Additional thunderstorms moved across far eastern Illinois during the evening producing a tornado and a few funnel clouds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Video and photos were shared of a brief landspout tornado that occurred in an open field.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated showers developed across north central Illinois during the evening of July 4th.  A landspout tornado was observed near one of these showers.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A video posted on social media confirmed a landspout tornado in a field behind a Menards store on the northeast side of Sterling, Illinois. The tornado was brief and occurred in an open field. No damage was observed to assign an EF-Scale rating.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The afternoon of July 8th, strong to severe storms moved across northwest Illinois. A few of these storms produced damaging winds and in one location, a brief landspout tornado that caused no damage near Sterling, Illinois.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in a field 2 miles northwest of Green Valley at 1:37 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northward and quickly dissipated at 1:38PM CDT.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from near Kansas City on the morning of July 15th to southern Lake Michigan by midnight on July 16th.  The low interacted with an unstable and very moist environment to produce a Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) over eastern Kansas into Missouri, which then pushed into west-central Illinois by the mid to late morning of July 15th.  Several rounds of convection moved across the Illinois River Valley through the afternoon, producing heavy rain and isolated wind damage.  The heaviest rainfall of 5 to 7 inches was focused across Tazewell, Woodford, and far eastern Peoria counties where significant flash flooding occurred.  In addition, 5 weak tornadoes touched down...including 2 in Tazewell County, 1 in McLean County, 1 in Morgan County, and 1 in Montgomery County which then crossed into southern Sangamon County.  Minor damage was reported with some of the tornadoes: however, no injuries or deaths occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in a field 1 mile north of South Pekin at 1:45 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northward and quickly dissipated at 1:46 PM CDT.  No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from near Kansas City on the morning of July 15th to southern Lake Michigan by midnight on July 16th.  The low interacted with an unstable and very moist environment to produce a Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) over eastern Kansas into Missouri, which then pushed into west-central Illinois by the mid to late morning of July 15th. Minor damage was reported with some of the tornadoes: however, no injuries or deaths occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in a field 1.6 miles southeast of Gridley at 4:04 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northward and quickly dissipated at 4:05 PM CDT.  No damage was reported.

Minor damage was reported with some of the tornadoes: however, no injuries or deaths occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 3.5 miles north-northwest of Waverly at 4:28PM CDT.  The tornado tracked north-northeastward and crossed into Sangamon County 4.5 miles north of Waverly at 4:30 PM CDT.  Minor crop and tree damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from near Kansas City on the morning of July 15th to southern Lake Michigan by midnight on July 16th.  The low interacted with an unstable and very moist environment to produce a Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) over eastern Kansas into Missouri, which then pushed into west-central Illinois by the mid to late morning of July 15th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado is a continuation of the tornado that touched down in Morgan County at 4:28 PM CDT.  It crossed from Morgan County into Sangamon County 5.6 miles southwest of New Berlin at 4:30 PM CDT, then tracked north-northeastward and dissipated 2.5 miles southwest of New Berlin at 4:37 PM CDT.  Minor crop and tree damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from near Kansas City on the morning of July 15th to southern Lake Michigan by midnight on July 16th.  The low interacted with an unstable and very moist environment to produce a Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) over eastern Kansas into Missouri, which then pushed into west-central Illinois by the mid to late morning of July 15th.  Several rounds of convection moved across the Illinois River Valley through the afternoon, producing heavy rain and isolated wind damage.  The heaviest rainfall of 5 to 7 inches was focused across Tazewell, Woodford, and far eastern Peoria counties where significant flash flooding occurred.  In addition, 5 weak tornadoes touched down...including 2 in Tazewell County, 1 in McLean County, 1 in Morgan County, and 1 in Montgomery County which then crossed into southern Sangamon County.  Minor damage was reported with some of the tornadoes: however, no injuries or deaths occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two spotters reported a tornado briefly touched down in a field verified with a picture.  This tornado touched down northeast of Hettick, IL, southwest of Otter Lake.  The tornado was very short lived and did not damage any rating indicators, thus it will be labeled an EF-unknown.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region triggering showers and storms. Some of the storms produced damaging winds and a couple of tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of a ground survey and satellite data shows an intermittent tornado path. The tornado touched down just south of Prange Avenue. It snapped and uprooted some trees near a residence on Prange Avenue. Satellite data shows the tornado continued northeast through cornfields, damaging more trees near Sewing and Mt. Olive Trails. Satellite data shows the tornado continued northeast, before lifting just west of Niemanville Trail. The tornado was rated as EF0 with a path length of 3.2 miles and max path width of 75 yards.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region triggering showers and storms. Some of the storms produced damaging winds and a couple of tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of a ground survey and satellite data suggests a brief, weak tornado touched down northeast of Walshville, IL. The tornado first touched down in a corn field west of Durbin Road. The tornado then continued northeast, mainly causing tree damage, though some minor structural damage to a house west of Durbin Road also occurred. The tornado quickly lifted as it approached Durbin Road. The tornado was rated as EF0 with a path length of 0.57 miles and max path width of 50 yards.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region triggering showers and storms. Some of the storms produced damaging winds and a couple of tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado developed about 3 miles north-northwest of Farmersville, Illinois, near the intersection of Rovey Lane and East 1st Road. A few storm chasers captured video of the tornado as it moved northeast and then north toward the Montgomery and Sangamon County line. On video the tornado appeared to be multivortex and violent, yet damage in the St. Louis county warning area was limited to a few broken tree branches, flattened corn and the partial destruction of a small outbuilding. Therefore, it was rated as an EF-0 in Montgomery County with a path length of 3.89 miles and a max path width of 300 yards. The tornado continued north into Sangamon County (WFO Central IL CWA) before lifting and dissipating about 2.4 miles south of Divernon. Overall, the tornado was rated EF0 with a total path length of 4.24 miles and a max path width of 300 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region triggering showers and storms. Some of the storms produced damaging winds and a couple of tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This is a continuation of a tornado that touched down in the National Weather Service St. Louis County Warning Area (CWA) in Montgomery County at 5:18 PM CDT.  The tornado crossed into the National Weather Service Central Illinois CWA in far southern Sangamon County at 5:25 PM CDT.  Damage occurred to approximately 15 acres of a cornfield before the tornado dissipated 2.7 miles south of Divernon at 5:26 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from near Kansas City on the morning of July 15th to southern Lake Michigan by midnight on July 16th.  The low interacted with an unstable and very moist environment to produce a Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) over eastern Kansas into Missouri, which then pushed into west-central Illinois by the mid to late morning of July 15th.  Several rounds of convection moved across the Illinois River Valley through the afternoon, producing heavy rain and isolated wind damage.  The heaviest rainfall of 5 to 7 inches was focused across Tazewell, Woodford, and far eastern Peoria counties where significant flash flooding occurred.  In addition, 5 weak tornadoes touched down...including 2 in Tazewell County, 1 in McLean County, 1 in Morgan County, and 1 in Montgomery County which then crossed into southern Sangamon County.  Minor damage was reported with some of the tornadoes: however, no injuries or deaths occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A very small tornado caused some minor damage at a country club on the northeast edge of Metropolis. The entire event was captured on video. The narrow funnel appeared to develop from the ground upward. The funnel briefly came in contact with the cloud base before it dissipated. There was no apparent large-scale parent mesocyclone. At the country club, tree limbs and a medium sized tree were blown over. A wood fence surrounding a port-a-potty was blown over, and another port-a-potty was blown over. Nobody was occupying the port-a-potty at the time of the tornado. Peak winds were estimated at 65 to 75 mph based on damage photos.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large clusters of thunderstorms increased in coverage and intensity during the afternoon along an east to west corridor across southeast Missouri into extreme southern Illinois and western Kentucky. The storms produced very heavy rainfall, along with an isolated brief tornado. The storms formed along and ahead of a slow-moving frontal boundary that extended generally along the Ohio River into southeast Missouri. The environment near and south of the front was characterized by dew points in the lower to middle 70's and precipitable water values around 1.75 inches. With daytime heating, instability increased substantially to around 3000 J/kg south of the front, with a sharp gradient along the surface front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 2.7 miles west-northwest of Auburn at 4:05 PM CDT.  The tornado tracked northeastward, destroying 2 large sheds and 2 grain bins.  It blew over an RV, damaged numerous trees, and caused minor roof damage to 2 houses and 2 large pole barns.  The tornado also damaged around 100 acres of corn and soybeans before dissipating near the intersection of Illinois Route 4 and Curran Road about 1.1 miles north of Auburn at 4:09 PM CDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary frontal boundary triggered several rounds of showers and thunderstorms on July 21st.  One cluster of storms tracked through east-central Illinois during the late morning, blowing down a few trees and power lines across portions of Piatt and Champaign counties.  Additional convection developed further west toward midday, with a line of storms then progressing eastward across much of central Illinois during the afternoon.  Scattered wind damage occurred with this line, while one cell produced an EF-1 tornado near Auburn in Sangamon County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management relayed a report of a brief tornado just northeast of intersection of Black Diamond Trail and North 35th Avenue. The tornado occurred over a field, resulting in no observed damage. The tornado was rated EFU (Unknown) with a path length 0.2 miles and max path width of 10 yards.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A remnant MCV moved across the region triggering showers and storms. Some of the storms became severe and produced damaging winds and large hail.
